For moose even more than salt it's calcium they're after (and to a certain degree phosphorus). They need it because their antlers, weighting up to 60 pounds, are mainly calcium and they grow them every year. This takes so much calcium they they can actually damage their bones growing said antlers as their body will strip calcium from their skeleton to make the antlers. Certain aquatic plants concentrate calcium and moose have a distinct preference for them.

The salt is incidental to the calcium and other mineral needs, it just so happens that the salt is often found in conjunction with the minerals the moose needs.

When it comes to primates, Crab-eating Macaques (aka Long-tailed Macaques) and Rhesus Macaques are excellent swimmers, can dive, and swim for pleasure often.

Well, if they weigh less than 14 lbs they do because all bowling balls are the same size in terms of diameter and circumference so that they fit the ball return machines. So to vary the weight but keep those same dimensions, the lighter ones have to be less dense. Fun experiment, put a 15 lb ball in a bucket of water or a big aquarium is more visually pleasing, and it sinks straight away. Take a 14 lb ball, exactly the same size, and it will sort of hover at the water's surface not floating really but not sinking. Take a 13 lb ball that looks identical and it will be sitting on top of the water.

This whole episode just isn't very well thought-out, IMO.

Why are most mammals innately able to swim and humans aren't? The same reason most mammals are innately able to walk, run, jump, and otherwise control their bodies, and humans aren't. It isn't just swimming that we have to learn from scratch; it's all body movement. I don't understand why it's so shocking to learn that an animal that pops out of the womb able to immediately walk, can also immediately swim.

How do they know how to swim? The same way they know how to walk. It's very useful as a survival technique to be able to ambulate in a variety of environments, so there's a positive evolutionary pressure there toward ambulatory ability from birth.

Why do animals that don't normally live in or around water know how to swim? Well, I mean... because creationism isn't a thing? Nobody went out to design kangaroos and thought, "Should I give them the power of swimming, or no?" Kangaroos evolved from some slightly earlier ancestor that knew how to swim, which evolved from some earlier ancestor that knew how to swim, all the way back to creatures that always swam.

The real question isn't "why are most mammals innately able to swim?"; it's "why aren't humans innately able to swim?" And the answer to that is the same as the reason why humans aren't innately able to walk, or hold our heads aloft, or crawl, or accurately move our hands, or think our feet might be foreign objects at first: our brains are too big for our pelvic passages, so we have to come out too early. Basically, all humans are severely premature, by the standards of most mammals. We come out bizarrely hairless, underdeveloped, with squishy joints that haven't finished fully forming yet, and almost no innate knowledge or abilities.

And... emulate other animals to swim better? Seriously? We are not shaped like any other animal. Why would we swim like they do? Once we do learn to swim, we're actually quite good at it compared to most land mammals. We're long, slender, streamlined, and have extremely powerful butts and thighs powering fairly wide, wedge-shaped feet. There is a swimming stroke that emulates most other mammals: the doggy paddle. And it's... really not very good.

Back in 1999 a moose managed to cross the Øresund Straight between southern Sweden and Zealand, the largest island of Denmark. Øresund is at an average around 15 km wide with quite a lot of current to it, being a major link for ships leaving the Baltic Sea and into the Atlantic. This was the first time in, roughly, 4.500 years, that a moose had been in Denmark outside of zoos, so it caught quite a lot of attention, though people were advised to keep at a distance, mostly for the sake of the moose. Unfortunately, after living peacefully, the singular moose was killed as it was struck by a train.

In 2015 a small amount of moose was released inside a wildlife reservation, in the hopes of increasing the local biodiversity.
